section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Emily Jenkins and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki
section-block.rac_book_summary: This narrative text introduces us to five creatures, three humans and two cats, who live together. Members of this family of five share some surprising likes and dislikes, leading to some very interesting groupings!

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64276-6. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Five Creatures by Emily Jenkins, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2001 by Emily Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2001 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_body-text: Practice counting items together as a group. Model counting with one-to-one correspondence and then ask children to do the same.
Sing a counting song with children, like “Five Little Ducks.” Use your fingers to show the amount of ducks each time you sing a number.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Introduce the Read Aloud Big Book
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Five Creatures written by Emily Jenkins and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki.
You know that Lala loves all sorts of books. She loves finding ways to count in stories like this one!
As I read the book to you, I want you to also think about your answer to this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How is this family like your family?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: Allow multiple opportunities to count the creatures in the book. Count the groups in different orders, noting that the total number of creatures is always five.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This book is about five creatures in a house—three people and two cats. Who can point to the five creatures on this page?
Who can come to the book and point to the three creatures with red hair? Who can point to the two creatures with gray hair?
section.rac_body-text: Count the three redheads while pointing and saying the numerals aloud. Then count the two with gray hair and ask,
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many creatures in all?
Which three creatures can button buttons? How many can’t button buttons? Are there still five in all?
How many creatures like birds? What does “but not all in the same way” mean?
Let’s answer the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How is this family like your family?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: My family has a mommy in it.
My family drinks milk and so does the family in the book.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences describing the different creatures that live in a house.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does your family also drink milk?
How is this family different from your family?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children can practice enhancing their working memory and sustaining their attention by comparing numbers and measurements. Children will need to hold information about each set in their minds as they think about and compare sets.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Working Memory
section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that their memories and brains are working all day long. Ask them to name something they need to remember, like daily routines, the order of putting on socks and shoes, or where they put a toy. Tell them that their minds can hold lots of information at once, which helps them solve problems or accomplish their goals.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread Five Creatures written by Emily Jenkins and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki to look closer at some parts of the book.
Clifford uses Mind Builders while he reads. Today, he will use his working memory to understand what he reads.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Our goal today is to think about how we use our working memory to understand the story.
Does anyone want to share another goal you are working on?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the word humans here. How many humans are in this story? Who are the humans? Are they the only creatures in this family?

We can use our working memory to figure out which creature does not like fish. When we look at the pictures, we need to remember to look for four creatures who like fish. Who can point to four creatures who like fish? How can you tell? Now we also know who does not like fish! (MB)
How many total creatures like to sing? Can you remember how many liked to sing at night? In the morning? (MB)
I think that girl’s goal is to learn to read. Do you have any reading goals? (MB)
Which two creatures can’t get down from trees? How do you know? You use your working memory to keep the words on the page in your mind as you look at the pictures. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children a specified number of items to find around the classroom. Have them use their working memory to keep track of how many items they found and still need to find. Once children gather their items, have children share their strategies for keeping the number in mind as they walked around the room.
Transcribe children’s observations counting, comparing, and contrasting creatures who live in their house.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children need to remember steps to solve a problem or complete a task. When presenting a multi-step task, you might want to provide ways to help them remember each step. For example, there might be a hand motion associated with each subtask, or you could chant the steps rhythmically to boost retention. (Diamond, 2007)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about how to decide whether someone is shorter or taller. Have children stand in a row in height order. Demonstrate how to stand next to one another to compare.
Help children practice sorting by attribute. Share a group of items and ask children to divide them into same and different. Work with them to re-sort by a different attribute.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Five Creatures written by Emily Jenkins and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki.
Lala loves reading books that tell us stories. Those are called narratives.
As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Which activities do some of the creatures do together?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Which three creatures are short? Which two are tall? How can we tell which creatures are tall and which creatures are short?
I see the word long. How are short and long different? Who in this class has short hair? Who has long hair?
Which creature cannot open cupboards? Why? The girl is too short to reach the cupboards.
This says the stools are high. We could also call them tall. Why can’t the girl get on the high stool?
If four creatures can get on the stools, and one can’t, are there still five creatures in all? How do you know?
Only three creatures can hide in boxes. Why can these creatures fit inside the box, but the grown-ups cannot?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? Which activities do some of the creatures do together? (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to this question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Three creatures like to climb trees.
Four creatures sit on the high stools.
Three creatures hide in boxes together.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you describe how to compare and contrast the size of two objects.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What activity do the creatures like to do outside?
The girl and her cats like to climb tr___ (trees).
The girl and her cats like to climb trees.
Which activities do all of the creatures do together?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Some multilingual learners might not feel comfortable speaking the academic language required by school subjects. When discussing measurement terms, which are necessary for both math and science instruction, provide concrete examples and explain measurement terms in the child’s first language.

section-block.rac_body-text: Play “duck, duck. goose,” but use “grandparent, grandparent, grandchild,” or other family titles, instead.
Invite children to share the names they call their grandmother or another older family figure. Make a list for all the children to see.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read My Family and Me. It is an informational poster about different members of families.
Five Creatures and My Family and Me are both about families. Let’s look for any connections between the two as we read!
Let’s think about how the poster connects to this week’s question:
What makes a family?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to discuss these prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: You can have mothers, brothers, and sisters in your family. How many creatures do you see here?
You can have grandparents, grandchildren, or pets in your family. How many pets are in Five Creatures? How many pets are in this picture?
You can have fathers and brothers in your family. How many brothers do you see?
Do you have aunts, uncles, and cousins in your family?
You can have parents and sisters in your family. How many parents are in Five Creatures?

section.rac_body-text: Have children act like different members of a family. Call out a family member, human or animal, and allow children to pretend to be that creature. Children can base their actions on their own experiences or what they have seen in the books this week.
Provide a writing prompt comparing and contrasting family members.

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Your Family and You
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Each family is unique and is comprised of different members. Families can build a sense of belonging and sense of security. One of the guiding principles for school readiness is that learning occurs within the context of relationships, both at home and at school. These interactions are essential to children’s learning.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to quietly act out measurement words like long, short, and tall with their bodies. Make it fun by switching words quickly.
Gather all of the dot Number Cards showing five or fewer dots. Show children the cards one at a time for two seconds and have them call out how many dots they see.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Five Creatures written by Emily Jenkins and illustrated by Tomek Bogacki one last time this week.
Lala wonders if you remember: does this book tell a story or teach true information?
We learned about counting and how families can be made of all kinds of creatures, even pets! When we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is something all the creatures in your family like to do that this family also does?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time and act out parts of the story.
Look at the creatures in this book!
section.rac_body-text: Ask for volunteers to act like the mother, father, girl, and two cats.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who are the creatures in your family?
How many grownups are in your family? Show me on your fingers. How many children? How many animals?
Do any members of your family like to eat fish? Drink milk? Eat mice? Eat beets?
What foods does your family like eating together? Let’s pretend to cook the food and eat it. Yum!
Pretend that you’re really tall and you can open cupboards. Really reach up high!
Now pretend you’re small enough to fit under the fridge. Get tiny!
Did that tree look short or tall? Show me how big it is with your hands.
Let’s pretend to climb up the tree. Now, climb down the tree.
Let’s talk about the question for today. What is something all the creatures in your family like to do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share with the group.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The people in my family also like to read books.
We all like to drink milk!
All the creatures in my family like to play outside too.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write to compare themselves to someone in their family.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does your family like to read books?
My family likes to read b______ (books).
My family likes to read books.
How can you compare your family to another family?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The ability to compare numbers and understand measurements begins with observations. A child may notice that her brother is short and her sister is tall. A child could have more aunts than uncles. As children grow older, they make increasingly complex observations and include greater detail in their descriptions.
